review.title: Very Short Literature Survey From Supervised Learning To Surrogate Modeling
review.abstract: The past century was era of linear systems. Either systems (especially industrial ones) were simple (quasi)linear or linear approximations were accurate enough. In addition, just at the ending decades of the century profusion of computing devices were available, before then due to lack of computational resources it was not easy to evaluate available nonlinear system studies. At the moment both these two conditions changed, systems are highly complex and also pervasive amount of computation strength is cheap and easy to achieve. For recent era, a new branch of supervised learning well known as surrogate modeling (meta-modeling, surface modeling) has been devised which aimed at answering new needs of modeling realm. This short literature survey is on to introduce surrogate modeling to whom is familiar with the concepts of supervised learning. Necessity, challenges and visions of the topic are considered.

sections.heading: Numerical Simulation:
sections.text: After deciding on the next samples to be evaluated, these points are sent to the system / simulator to obtain outputs.

sections.heading: Construction of surrogate modeling:
sections.text: As with classic model design, surrogate modeling has a number of options for constructing a model based on e.g. Support Vector Machines (SVM).3 In some references, this step is also referred to as examples of Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), Kriging, Polynomial Regressors, Spline, Guassian Process, Radial Base Functions, etc. As already mentioned, the selection of a suitable model is not directly considered in classical modeling tools within the training loop, and it is a matter that depends more on personal experience. However, there are some reports of surrogate modeling that automate this task. Surrogate modeling is usually considered black box modeling. In its pure form, this assertion may be correct, but in available toolboxes such as SUMO, iSight, etc., it is also possible to overwork the modeling toolbox using some limitations that experts suggest.

sections.heading: Validation Process:
sections.text: These problems usually fall into one of four types: Model Approximation, Design Space Exploration, where a visual view of the system is sought, Problem Formulation, where the meta-model helps the engineer choose appropriate optimization criteria and appropriate boundaries for constraints, and finally Optimization Support, where the environment model is used as a substitute for classic gradient-based optimization. Successful implementation of this last use represented a good picture of surrogate modeling that led to meta-modeled design optimization (MBDO). To finish this line, we must understand that Fig.3 is not the only iteration loop.

sections.heading: 4.3 Uncertainity in Metamodeling
sections.text: Metamodeling can be used to filter noise in computer simulation. On the other hand, uncertainty in metamodeling brings new challenges in design optimization. If optimization problems are limited, it becomes apparent that the limited optimum is very sensitive to the accuracy of all metamodeling when both limitations and objective functions are complex to calculate and metamodeling is applied. Mathematically rigorous methods must be developed to qualify the uncertainty of a metamodeling.
